project.name: recruiters
project.description: The recruiters subproject provides a central location for information about developer recruitment and recruiter policy.
project.longdescription: Gentoo's true strength is its impressive and constantly evolving developer base. It's the job of recruiters to manage the growth of the development team by locating, approving, and managing new developers to add further innovative talent to our already strong organization.

extrachapter.title: What does it take to be a recruiter?

body.p: Recruiters need to possess several talents in order to successfully oversee additions to the development team. First and foremost, a recruiter needs to be a good judge of character. While most new developer sponsors pick only the best candidates, there have been and will be occasional duds. Recruiters need to be able to analyze an individual's background, experience, and past contributions, then use that information to decide whether or not to accept a developer. Recruiters also need to be aware of the big picture in order to recognize weaknesses in the organization and accept devs who will shore up those weaknesses. Remember, recruiters always have the final say on new developers. Never be afraid to say no, but always offer a detailed explanation of the decision.

extrachapter.title: What does the recruitment process involve?

body.p: First, an existing developer sponsors a new developer. The sponsor must be willing to be a mentor to the new developer. Mentors are responsible for pointing mentees to developer-related documentation, answering questions, explaining the ins and outs of working for Gentoo as much as possible, and assisting/supporting the new developer even past the required two week training period. A new developer bug must be filed on our Bugzilla by the sponsor or a recruiter. Feel free to ask an experienced recruiter for information on what a good new developer bug consists of.

A two week probationary period for training and review begins when the new developer bug is filed, assuming it is not rejected by recruiters. The mentor should be in regular contact with their mentee to regularly review their work and offer suggestions and constructive criticism. Please note that two weeks is the absolute required minimum, but definitely not the maximum. Mentors and recruiters should both be confident in the new developer before proceeding.

At the end of the two week period, a questionnaire should be filled out by the mentee. This is not a pass/fail examination by any means. The questionnaire is intended to make sure new developers carefully read both developer policy and technical documentation. This should be emailed to recruiters@gentoo.org along with a scanned copyright assignment agreement and a SSH DSA public key. When recruiters and the mentor both agree that a new developer is ready and all the relevant information has been received, access to Gentoo infrastructure is granted.

extrachapter.title: Checklist for adding a new developer

body.p: Make sure that the new developer has operator status in #gentoo-dev. Seemant, avenj, rac, cybersystem, and spyderous currently have access to add operators.

Add the developer's account to dev.gentoo.org (emu.gentoo.org). Check /etc/passwd for the last developer account. Please note that other types of accounts exist and they have UIDs in different ranges. Run sudo /usr/sbin/superadduser. For the UID, use 1+the last one you saw. The rest is just defaults, other than the real name. Set a password so that the user can login and change it for mail purposes. Run sudo /usr/bin/vim /home/(new developer name)/.ssh/authorized_keys and paste their SSH public key there. Have them confirm that they can login via SSH. If there are problems, doublecheck the SSH key. The developer should be told to change their password from the one you assigned, and then pointed to the developer email how-to to set up email.

If they need CVS access to the Portage tree, ping avenj, seemant or spyderous. If you have the permissions to do it, login to the CVS box and run: sudo /usr/sbin/superadduser and give them the same UID as on the dev box. Also make sure to add them to the cvs group (and leave them in the default users group). If you do not have access to the CVS server, contact avenj.

Contact dmwaters, sj7trunks, or klieber to subscribe them to the -core developer-only mailing list. Additionally, if they are presently subscribed to any Gentoo mailing lists, they should unsubscribe and resubscribe with their Gentoo address.

Edit their current Bugzilla login and change it to their gentoo account. While you're in there, make sure their real name is in the Name field. Do not change their Bugzilla password. If you do not have access to edit users in Bugzilla, contact avenj.
Ping rac, brandy, or one of the other forums administrators to update their status on the Gentoo Forums, if applicable. Forums accounts are not required.

Finally, send an email to the gentoo-dev mailing list to introduce them to the developer and user community. In your introduction, you may be funny, as that seems to be the normal way to introduce a developer, but please explicitly state their reason for being a developer (primary herds, other gentoo related projects, etc).
Please follow up with the developer during their first month to make sure they are getting along and staying off the drugs.
